snippet: With a switch to longer extra points, the Canadian Football League has become a laboratory for the N.F.L., which was also introducing longer kicks to add more uncertainty to games.
abstract: Canadian Football League has seen success rate of extra-point kicks fall from 99.5 percent to 86.2 percent since implementing new rule that lengthens kicks from 12 to 32 yards; after only five weeks of play success rate was 80.6 percent and it has been steadily rising as kickers learn new techniques; NFL will also have longer kicks with start of 2015 season.
lead_paragraph: With a switch to longer extra points, the Canadian Football League has become a laboratory for the N.F.L., which was also introducing longer kicks to add more uncertainty to games.

headline.main: As N.F.L. Prepares for Longer Extra Points, C.F.L. Offers a Preview
headline.print_headline: C.F.L. Offers a Preview of the N.F.L.’s Longer Extra Points
